column2: Air-Independent Propulsion (AIP) is a term that encompasses technologies which allow a submarine to operate without the need to surface or rely on a snorkel to access atmospheric oxygen. The term usually excludes the use of nuclear power, and describes augmenting or replacing the traditional diesel-electric propulsion system of non-nuclear vessels. The United States Navy uses the hull classification symbol SSP to designate boats powered by AIP.

With the introduction of dedicated heavy machine-cannon coupled with innovative oblique firing installations, in German known as "Schräge Musik" or Oblique Music, by the end of 1942, night fighters were no longer simply heavy fighters equipped with a radar in the nose. Rather, they were specialised bomber-stalkers packing a powerful punch. No longer did the fighter have to approach the target bomber from the rear.

In order to continue the night fighter's advantage against bombers, more advanced radar and targeting systems were developed. At the forefront of such advanced targeting systems were the Germans with armament such as the SG500 Jägerfaust or the SG 116 'Zellendusche'. Both operated with photo-sensitive electric triggers to perfectly time the firing as the pilot flew under the shadow of the bomber.

Military aviation came into its own during the Second World War. The increased performance, range, and payload of contemporary fighter aircraft meant that air power could move beyond the novelty applications of WWI, becoming a central striking force for all the combatant nations.
This tech allows you to research signal equipment for your land units.

Add a signal battalion to your infantry brigades in order to make them follow your orders more quickly. A Signal battalion is specialised in providing communications for both operational and administrative functions.

Add a signal battalion to your armoured brigades in order to make them able to better pierce enemy lines. A signal battalion is a specialised form of military unit dedicated to providing communications for both operational and administrative functions.

Military intelligence, commonly abbreviated as milint, is a military service that uses intelligence gathering disciplines to collect information which may be of use in the decision-making process of Commanders.

German combat experience with the external turret-mounted smoke discharge candles led to instances of tank crews being incapacitated by the smoke from their own smoke dispensers when they were ignited by small arms fire. The other German concern was for protecting tanks against infantry in close fighting. The solution was to move the smoke discharge system under the armour.

As tanks are developed and infantry becomes increasingly mobile, our support brigades need similar mechanization to fight alongside them. Self-propelled artillery and tank destroyers provide fast, tough support brigades for our divisions.
Medium Tank Destroyer design relies on the Medium Tank chassis and specialized AT guns.
Heavy Tank Destroyer design relies on the Heavy Tank chassis and specialized high caliber AT guns.

By taking the concept of the heavy tank to its logical limit, we can develop super heavy tank brigades. These colossal tanks almost amount to mobile fortifications, and against almost all ground attacks their thick armour offers excellent protection. Moreover, their massive guns pose a threat to anything that opposes them. However, they are vastly expensive to build and operate and are still vulnerable to flanking tactics and air attack.

While most armies still maintained cavalry units at the outbreak of World War II in 1939, significant mounted action was largely restricted to the Polish, Balkan and Soviet campaigns. A more correct term should be 'mounted infantry' instead of 'cavalry', as horses were primarily used as a means of transportation. However we can decide to make our cavalry more based on motorcycles and trucks.

Since the development of armored warfare the distinction between light and heavy cavalry has persisted basically along historic lines. Cavalry units have adopted armored cars and light tanks in order to become a more capable reconnaissance force.

The ability to build huge transport planes opens up the opportunity to insert heavily armed paratrooper divisions behind enemy lines. Heavy paratroopers require triple the cargo space but they still retain sufficent firepower.

The Imperial Japanese Navy fielded naval paratroopers during World War II. The troops were officially part of the Special Naval Landing Forces (SNLF or Rikusentai).\nThe Paramarines (also known as Marine paratroopers) was a short-lived specialized unit of the United States Marine Corps, trained to be dropped by parachute.

Jäger is a term that was adopted in the Enlightenment Era in German-speaking states and others influenced by German military practice to describe a kind of light infantry. While it literally means 'hunter' in German, in military contexts Jäger may be regarded as meaning 'rifleman' or 'fighter' (in the same sense as 'fighter aircraft'). Certain infantry divisions were raised as 'light infantry divisions' (leichte Infanterie-Divisionen) in late 1940 or were renamed 'light divisions' (leichte Divisionen) in late 1941. They were raised to operate in rough terrain, especially in southeastern Europe.

With the stubborn defence encountered during city fighting, it became necessary for specialised training and equipment to facilitate such assaults and neutralize the advantages inherent to the defenders.

Armoured Trains are equipped with railroad cars armed with artillery and machine guns. They offer an innovative way to quickly move large amounts of firepower. Their use was discontinued in most countries when road vehicles became much more powerful and offered more flexibility, and because armoured trains were too vulnerable to track sabotage as well as air attacks.
A floatplane is a fixed-wing aircraft capable of taking off and landing (alighting) on water and used for reconnaissance, search and rescue, and anti-submarine warfare.

High Frequency Direction Finding, HF/DF (pronounced 'Huff-Duff') is used to obtain the approximate location of an enemy vessel when that vessel uses its radio. Along with ASDIC (sonar), Ultra code breaking (COMINT) and radar, 'Huff-Duff' was a valuable part of the Allies' armoury for defeating German U-boats and commerce raiders during the Battle of the Atlantic.

Auxiliary Cruisers or Commerce Raiders may have been built as freighters, but they went to sea and fought as true warships. Freighters they were, and indeed some of them returned to being freighters after the war, but on the high seas between 1939 and 1945 they were real warships

The Depth Charge is an anti-submarine weapon intended to defeat its target by the shock of exploding near it. Most use explosives and a fuse set to go off at a predetermined depth. Depth charges can be deployed by both ships and aircraft.

The Light Aircraft Carrier (CVL) was a small, slow-moving type of aircraft carrier, typically half the length and one-third the displacement of the larger Fleet Carriers. While they were slower, less well armed and armoured, and carried fewer planes, they were less expensive and built in much larger numbers.

A midget submarine is any submarine under 150 tons, typically operated by a crew of one or two but sometimes up to 6 or 8, with little or no on-board living accommodations. Midget submarines are commonly armed with torpedoes and mines. Alternatively, they may carry timed explosive charges.

Other nations are developing up-to-date naval aircraft which are designed to operate from Aircraft Carriers. We should do likewise, and then we will be able to build Carrier Air Groups of specialized naval fighters and bombers.

Other nations are developing up-to-date naval aircraft which are designed to operate from Aircraft Carriers. We should do likewise, and then we will be able to build Carrier Air Groups of specialized naval fighters and bombers.

Other nations are developing up-to-date naval aircraft which are designed to operate from Aircraft Carriers. We should do likewise, and then we will be able to build Carrier Air Groups of specialized naval fighters and bombers.

A heavy fighter is a fighter aircraft designed to carry heavier weapons and/or operate at longer ranges. To achieve acceptable performance, most heavy fighters were twin-engined. Some extremely long-ranged heavy fighters are considered to be Escort Fighters.
A Night Fighter (also known as an All-Weather Fighter) is a heavy fighter aircraft adapted for use at night or for other times of bad visibility.

Long range radios, telephone lines, motorized transports and large numbers of Forward Observers (FOs) devise impromptu artillery fire capable of blunting multi-divisional enemy attacks. The mobility of artillery also meant they could follow their armored spearheads closely and be set up quickly to fire on new targets so offensive drives could be sustained longer and deeper behind enemy lines without the need to pause and reorganize.

The Colonial Forces was a general designation for the military forces that garrisoned and were largely recruited from several colonial empires from the late 17th century. This force played a substantial role in both World Wars.

The French Foreign Legion (French: Légion étrangère) is a unique unit in the French Army, established in 1831. The legion was specifically created for foreign nationals wishing to serve in the French Armed Forces, but commanded by French officers.

The SOMUA S35 was a French cavalry tank of the Second World War. Built from 1936 until 1940 to equip the armoured divisions of the Cavalry, it was for its time a relatively agile medium-weight tank, superior in armour and armament to both its French and foreign competitors such as the German Panzerkampfwagen III.

During the German expansion of the Second World War, numerous european governments and monarchs were forced to seek refuge in the United Kingdom rather than face certain destruction at the hands of the Nazis. Most of them called their citizens to arms and fight against the German directly from the UK islands.

The angled flight deck was designed for the higher landing speeds of jet aircraft in mind. Benefits included concurrent launch and recovery operations, and allowed aircraft failing to connect with the arrestor cables to abort the landing, accelerate, and relaunch without risk to other parked or launching aircraft. The redesign allowed for several other design and operational modifications, including the mounting of a larger island (improving both ship-handling and flight control), simplified aircraft recovery and deck movement (aircraft now launched from the bow and re-embarked on the angle, leaving a large open area amidships for arming and fueling), and damage control.

Airborne forces will have a great deal more firepower if heavy weapons can be developed which are compact enough to be transported via aircraft. The most common way of doing this is with towed gliders which are released over previously neutralised landing zones.

Military gliders are used for ferrying troops and heavy equipment to combat zones. These engine-less aircraft are towed into the air and most of the way to their target by military transport planes. Once released from the tow craft they are to land on any convenient open terrain close to the target and hopefully with as little damage to the cargo and crew as possible.

Fortified positions need to be assaulted by troops aided with special equipment. A division supported by armoured engineers can overcome most obstacles the enemy can put between them and their target.
Lend-Lease allows us to build more tanks, trucks and ammo. We should soon be able to optimize our production and build them more quickly and efficiently.

As the United States of America, you can't build regular Marine brigades, you have the Elite US Marines Corps instead. The USMC brigades start weak and will be strengthened with several events over the years. You will have to wait until mid to late 1941 and get the Landing Vehicle Tracked event before having the USMC at a real divisional level.

Pilot training is vital if we want to get the most from our of aircraft designs. Even simple things like training our pilots when best to shoot to conserve ammunition allows them to get the most out of our planes. These allow our fighter aircraft to both fight longer and more effectively.

The B-17 began World War II service with the RAF in 1941 and the USAAF Eighth Air Force and Fifteenth Air Force units in 1942. It was primarily involved in daylight precision strategic bombing against German industrial targets. Operation Pointblank guided attacks in preparation for a ground assault. During World War II, the B-17 equipped 32 overseas combat groups and dropped 640,036 tons (580,631 tonnes) of bombs on European targets.

The North American Aviation P-51 Mustang equipped with the famed Rolls-Royce Merlin engine,  was a long-range single-seat World War II fighter aircraft. Designed, built and airborne in just 117 days, the Mustang first flew in RAF service as a fighter-bomber and reconnaissance aircraft before conversion to a bomber escort employed in raids over Germany helping ensure Allied air superiority from early 1944.

Elite Marine units such as the US Marine Corps and the Japanese special Naval Landing Forces-Kaigun Tokubetsu Rikusentai- are responsible for providing Force Projection from the sea, using the mobility of the Navy to rapidly deliver combined-arms task forces.

Duplex Drive tanks were a type of amphibious swimming tanks developed by the British. The phrase is mostly used for the Duplex Drive variant of the M4 Sherman medium tanks, that was used by the Western Allies during and after the Normandy Landings in June 1944. DD tanks worked by erecting a 'flotation screen' around the tank, which would enable it to float, and had a 'Duplex Drive' water screw driven from the tank's engine.
To succeed in operations we need an effective command structure. This means having generals and staff who are well-trained and familiar with our modern operational units.

The United States Marine Corps (USMC) is a branch of the United States Navy responsible for providing force projection from the sea, using the mobility of the Navy to rapidly deliver combined-arms task forces.

Throughout the Pacific campaign during World War II, both the United States Army and the Marine Corps trained the new graduated recruits in joint-amphibious operations. Even the Army conducted its own facility to accommodate the training necessary establishing the Amphibious Training Center (ATC).

Following American entry into the war, the U.S. Navy grew tremendously as the United States was faced with a two-front war on the seas. It achieved notable acclaim in the Pacific Theater, where it was instrumental to the Allies' successful island hopping campaign. This required a tremendous effort with supplies and supply chains.

The Landing Vehicle Tracked (LVT) was a class of amphibious vehicles introduced by the United States Navy, Marine Corps and Army during World War II. Originally intended solely as cargo carriers for ship-to-shore operations, they rapidly evolved into assault troop and fire support vehicles as well. The types were all widely known as amphtrack, amtrak, amtrac etc., a play on "amphibious tractor".

On Jan 1 1943, the USMC changed the formation of its rifle squads to better fit the needs of jungle warfare. This change centered around the squad level organization by breaking the squad into 2 Fire Groups. Each Fire Group was built around an automatic rifle (BAR). The new structure also added additional machine gun sections and platoons up the chain of command. This effectively doubled USMC firepower and tactical organization.

These squad-level AT weapons were a light-weight, 1 or 2 man anti-tank weapon of World War II. They consisted of a small, disposable preloaded launch tube firing a high explosive anti-tank shaped warhead, made famous as the German "Panzerfaust" operated by a single soldier. The Bazooka and German Panzerschreck were also popular names for reusable anti-tank rocket launchers developed by the Germans and USA in World War II.
Equip Militia with infantry AT weapons
Armed with Panzerfausts and deeply entrenched, even a unit of Militia could cause serious trouble for any enemy armor.

The name could also describe newer and more powerful models, the FlaK 41 and 43, although these were different weapons. Compared to the British QF 3.7 inch AA gun or United States 90 mm gun models, the 88 was built in very large numbers, and when doubled in the anti-tank role, it was mounted on a versatile base from which it could be fired without unlimbering. Its success as an improvised anti-tank gun led to a separate line of guns for anti-tank use.

Because the Wehrmacht was lacking manpower to stop the Soviet advance, men in jobs not deemed necessary or previously deemed unfit for military service were now called to arms. The "Volkssturm" was founded on Adolf Hitler's orders October 18, 1944 and conscripted males between the ages of 16 to 60 years who were not already serving in some military unit as part of a German Home Guard.

The Waffen-SS (German for Armed SS, literally Weapons SS) was the combat arm of the Schutzstaffel (Protective Squadron) or SS, an organ of the Nazi Party. The Waffen-SS saw action throughout World War II and swelled from three regiments to over 38 divisions, and served alongside the Wehrmacht regular army, but was never formally part of it.

The Deutschland Class was a series of three Panzerschiffe (armoured ships), a form of heavily armed cruiser, built by the German Reichsmarine more or less in accordance with restrictions imposed by the Treaty of Versailles. The class is named after the first ship of this class to be completed (the Deutschland).
Tank optics played a huge role during the war, as not only did one require a gun capable of damaging an enemy target, but also one had to be able to hit it consistently.

German optics played a huge role during the war, as not only did one require a gun capable of damaging an enemy target, but also one had to be able to hit it consistently. In this aspect, the German firing optics were ahead of their Allied counterparts, especially the Soviets.

Hitlers orders to dig-in and not give ground leaves his soldiers few options to stem the tide of the advancing Red Army. The front-line troops can only hedgehog their positions, fight where they stand, obeying the No Retreat order, and pray for a mobile force to counterattack and throw the Soviets back.

Elastic Defence is a military strategy that seeks to delay rather than prevent the advance of an attacker, buying time and causing additional casualties by yielding space. Rather than defeating an attacker with a single, strong defensive line, defence in depth relies on the tendency of an attack to lose momentum over a period of time as it covers a larger area.

The Goliath transmitter was a VLF (Very Low Frequency) radio transmitter of the German Navy. It had a maximum transmission power of 1800 kW and was the main radio transmitter for submarine radio communications. Goliath's transmissions could be received worldwide including by submerged submarines in the Caribbean.
Do not be captured alive! After researching this tech an event will fire granting you a permanent morale bonus of 10% for all your troops.

The Sen Toku I-400-class submarines of the Imperial Japanese Navy were the largest submarines of World War II. They were submarine aircraft carriers able to carry three Aichi M6A Seiran aircraft underwater to their destinations. They were designed to surface, launch the planes then dive again quickly before they were discovered. They also carried torpedoes for close range combat.

The Kamikaze (common translation: Divine Wind) are suicide attacks by military aviators designed to destroy as many warships as possible. These units are expensive and can literally kill off large amounts of officers in one attack. However they are very effective at sinking enemy shipping.
Victory or Dishonour! doctrine. Train your infantry to be very resilient and continue to fight in difficult situations with very few supplies.

The Japanese infantry was able to move quickly and easily through the jungles of Malaysia and New Guinea due to having to manage fewer supplies and heavy equipment. They did this to a larger extent than the conventionl european version of light infantry and they were expert jungle fighters while the allied units were still locked into more conventional methods of fighting and supply.

Following Japan's disastrous losses at the Battle of Midway  in which four of Japan's six fleet carriers were lost  the decision was made to convert unfinished Battleship hulls to Aircraft Carriers. The conversions began in June 1942. The conversion process placed a heavy emphasis on flight-deck armor, similar to the design of the British Illustrious-class aircraft carriers. You can now upgrade Battleships to Battlecarriers on the map.

The Blackshirts (Italian: camicie nere, CCNN, or squadristi) were Fascist paramilitary groups in Italy from the period immediately following World War I and until the end of World War II. Blackshirts were also known as the National Security Volunteer Militia (Milizia Volontaria per la Sicurezza Nazionale, or MVSN).
Pack Artillery and Light Amphibious Artillery

A Light Artillery regiment consists of a field artillery regiment specialized in mountain combat and naval landings. They use smaller guns and lack field artillery firepower but they still create some chaos in the enemy lines.

The Bersaglieri (Marksmen) are a corps of the Italian Army originally created by General Alessandro La Marmora in 1836 to serve in the Piedmontese Army, later to become the Royal Italian Army. They have always been a high-mobility infantry unit.
To succeed in our offensive operations we need an effective command structure. This means Generals and staff who are well-trained and familiar with our modern operational units.

The Requetés (from the French requêté, hunting call) were the Carlist militia during the Spanish Civil War. Wearing red berets, they mostly came from Navarre and were highly religious with many regarding the war as a Crusade. They were often accompanied by priests as field chaplains, who were known for risking their lives to perform the Last Rites on the battlefield, and who also urged the men on.
Since we are on the same side, Germany will grant us foreign captured equipment and their old panzers in order to build an efficient armored force to better support them.
While the war is going on, we capture more and more equipment from the ennemy and are able to reinforce our armored brigades.

The Axis powers comprised the countries that were opposed to the Allies during World War II. The three major Axis powers, Germany, Japan, and Italy, were part of a military alliance with the signing of the Tripartite Pact in September 1940, which officially founded the Axis powers. At their zenith, the Axis powers ruled empires that dominated large parts of Europe, Africa, East and Southeast Asia and the Pacific Ocean.

The T-34 was a Soviet medium tank first produced in 1940. Although its armour and armament were surpassed by later tanks of the era, it has been often credited as the most effective, efficient and influential tank design of World War II. First produced at the KhPZ factory in Kharkov, it was the mainstay of Soviet armoured forces throughout World War II. It was the most-produced tank of the war, with 57,000 produced between 1940 and 1945.

Tank desant is a military combined arms tactic, where infantry soldiers ride into an attack on tanks, then dismount to fight on foot in the final phase of an assault. The tactic was used as an expedient by the Soviet Red Army during the Second World War. Tank desant troops (tankodesantniki) were infantry, trained in the tactic in order to offer small arms support in suppression of enemy anti-tank weapons, or enemy infantry using anti-tank grenades.

Mechanized warfare is the use of armoured fighting vehicles. It is a major component for new methods of warfare. The premise of mechanized warfare rests on the ability of troops to penetrate conventional defensive lines through use of manoeuvre by armoured units. Much of the application of mechanized warfare depends on the use of tanks and related tracked vehicles used by other supporting arms such as infantry fighting vehicles and self-propelled artillery.

[You will be able to adopt this order if Germany controls Odessa, Kiev and Smolensk]Some foolish people at the front comfort themselves by saying that we can always retreat further east, since we have much territory, much land and manpower, and that we will always have more than enough grain. They say this to excuse their shameful conduct at the front. But such talk are lies and falsehoods, and only helps our enemies.

The Soviet Union expanded its indigenous arms industry as part of Stalin's industrialization program in the 1920s and 1930s. Notable Soviet tanks include the T-34, often cited as the best tank of the war. Small arms used during the Second World War included, for example, the Mosin-Nagant Rifle, which was also used as a sniper rifle and the PPSh sub-machine gun.
Now that the Stalin Line is taken back, we can cancel Order No.227 and let the soldiers withdraw if they think this is necessary.

By 1943 after the disasterous early years of Operation Barbarossa, the Red Army was finally in a position to begin the full scale implementation of innovative doctrines and organisational structures developed during the interwar period and mass produce the necessary equipment and military hardware to go along with these changes.

The German invasion in 1941 led to a series of staggering defeats for the Russians. In the first five months of fighting the Soviets lost several million men. The Soviet Union needs to organize patriotic people defending the Motherland quickly!
In August 1937 the Commissariat of Defense reinstituted Dual Command at regimental level and higher. Now just as during the Civil War all military orders had to be counter-signed by a Commissar.

The doctrine established that the army would be led by a cadre of regular (career) leaders rather than elected leaders (Commissars). And would continue to have centralized authority, not local, as had the Red Guards and partisans.
Make our artillery shells blow out the sun !

A self-propelled anti-aircraft weapon (SPAA, also self-propelled air defense) is an anti-aircraft gun mounted on a mobile vehicle chassis. Specific weapon systems include machine guns, auto-cannon or larger guns. Platforms used include both trucks and heavier armoured fighting vehicles such as APCs and tanks, which add protection from aircraft, artillery counter-fire, and small arms fire for front line deployment.

Siege Artillery are heavy guns and other bombardment devices designed to bombard fortifications, cities, and other fixed targets. They are capable of firing massive shells but require enormous transport and logistical support to operate. They lack mobility and thus are rarely useful in more mobile warfare situations.

An assault gun is a gun or howitzer mounted on a motor vehicle or armoured chassis designed for use in the direct-fire role in support of infantry when attacking other infantry or fortified positions. Historically the custom-built fully armoured assault guns or howitzers are mounted in a fully enclosed casemate on a tank chassis.

Historically the custom-built fully armoured assault guns or howitzers are mounted in a fully enclosed casemate on a tank chassis.
Surveillance aircraft are military aircraft used for monitoring enemy activity, usually carrying no armament.
Researching smaller, powerful and more mobile radio communications for infantry provides much better command and control. Infantry tactics and combat capabilities greatly improve as a result.

The Waffen-SS's elite armored units, acting as fire brigades and crack assault units on all fronts. Equipped with Tiger and Tiger II tanks the kill-to-loss ratio of these units was extremely high. The limited number of these heavy tanks, plus their specialized role in either offensive or defensive missions meant they were rarely permanently assigned to a single division or corps

Poorly armed and composed of politically indoctrinated volunteers from various nations. Fascist milita units played a key role in the war behind the lines, fighting partisans and keeping supply lines clear. These units are quick and cheap to raise with an added bonus of being good partisan fighters themselves.

Ski troops played a key role in snow-bound terrain. Forested, rural terrain with no roads was used by ski troops with great success against any enemy. Most notably in the Battle of Suomussalmi two Soviet mechanized divisions (45000 men) were annihilated by three Finnish regiments (11000 men).

Aircraft designed with very low wing loading (loaded weight of the aircraft divided by the area of the wing). No pilot armor or self sealing fuel tanks saves weight. Dispensing with such combat and safety features will help achieve superior range, speed and agility.
Research this tech if You want to switch from Light to Heavy Planes.

This will enable us to integrate our air defense assets to defend our industrial centres and population from bombing raids. It might mean taking some resources from the front, but the defense of our industry is important to the war effort.

The ability to organise and deploy garrisons overseas is vital for protecting a nation's global assets. Developing this capability allows our nation to use transports to ship Garrison Units across the oceans.
Understanding how to construct and maintain large Artillery enclosures which will allow even the most massive naval guns to be set up in defensive positions.
Highly mobile Infantry with Helicopter air-lift capability. The ultimate in rapid deployment and enemy suppression. These units are especially useful in areas of difficult terrain.

A special elite commando unit designed to damage infrasructure and buildings with pinpoint raids. These units have a short range and while they can't be intercepted, they can take heavy losses to ground based AA units. Use the Strike Commando to knock out enemy supply nodes, neutralise forts, radar installations, ports and airfields within their range.
Asymmetric warfare is war between belligerents whose relative military power differs significantly, or whose strategy or tactics differ significantly.

The basic German infantry section was nine men eight with rifles and one with a belt-fed light machine gun. Sub-machine guns and assault rifles in lieu of bolt-action rifles became more prevalent as the war progressed. Tactics focused on the machine gun, supplying it ammo and covering it's flanks. This focus led to formidable firepower and once-flanked sections would give ground slowly to set up new firing positions.
Medium Artillery allows more firepower and support in battle. The added size and weight of the guns means more powerful transport units should be considered if mobility is important
Motorisation of the supporting units gives better flexibility and adds tactical fire support to the infantry units.
The engine and chassis quality is important for the efficiency of the entire unit, both in transit and once combat has been joined.

With fuel shortages becoming desperate we have to save fuel wherever possible. Auxiliary vehicles and unnecessary vehicle usage are to be cut back. Horses can replace many of our trucks. In warfare the Hedgehog Defence is a military tactic for defending against a mobile armoured attack, or blitzkrieg. The defenders deploy in-depth in heavily fortified positions suitable for all-around defence. The attackers can penetrate between these "hedgehogs", but each position continues to fight-on when surrounded. This keeps large numbers of attacking troops tied up attacking the well-defended strongpoints. And allowing the defenders to successfully counterattack against the units that bypass these strongpoints with their own armored reserves by cutting them off from their supporting elements.

Defence-in-depth requires that a defender deploy his resources such as fortifications, field works, and military units at and well behind the front line. Although an attacker may find it easier to breach the more-weakly defended front line, as he advances he continues to meet resistance. As he penetrates deeper, the attacker's flanks become vulnerable, and, should the advance stall, the attacker risks being enveloped. The defence-in-depth strategy is particularly effective against an attacker who is able to concentrate his forces and attack a small number of places on an extended defensive line.

Deep operations had two phases, the tactical deep battle, followed by the exploitation of tactical success, known as the conduct of deep battle operations. Deep battle envisioned the breaking of the enemy's forward defences, or tactical zones, for fresh uncommitted mobile operational reserves to exploit by breaking into the strategic depth of an enemy front. The goal of a deep operation was to inflict a decisive strategic defeat on the enemy and render the defence of their front more difficult, impossible, or indeed, irrelevant. Unlike most other doctrines, Deep Battle stressed combined arms cooperation at all levels: strategic, operational, and tactical.
